code: @Misc{,   title = {PhenotypeSpace: an R package to quantify and compare phenotypic trait spaces},   author = {M. Araya-Salas and K. Odom},   year = {2022}, }

title: Quantifying phenotypic spaces
text: PhenotypeSpace intended facilitate quantification phenotypic space features. package offers functions : Estimate absolute values phenotypic spaces Compare trait spaces across groups Modify output formats facilitate statistical analysis functions allow parallelization tasks, distributes tasks among several processors improve computational efficiency. install latest developmental version github need R package remotes: Please cite PhenotypeSpace follows: Araya-Salas, M., & K. Odom. 2022. PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces. R package version 0.1.0.
code: remotes::install_github("maRce10/PhenotypeSpace")  #load package library(PhenotypeSpace)

title: PhenotypeSpace: Quantifying phenotypic spaces — PhenotypeSpace
text: Facilitates quantifying phenotypic trait spaces comparing spaces across groups.

title: PhenotypeSpace: Quantifying phenotypic spaces — PhenotypeSpace
text: package offers functions : Estimate absolute values phenotypic trait spaces Compare phenotypic trait spaces across groups Modify output formats facilitate statistical analysis functions allow parallelization tasks, distributes tasks among several processors improve computational efficiency. License: GPL (>= 2)

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: binary_triangular_matrix creates binary triangular matrices representing categorical data distance matrix form

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
code: binary_triangular_matrix(group, labels = NULL)

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: group Character vector factor containing categories represented pairwise binary matrix. Several observations per categories (least categories) required. labels Character vector factor containing labels used rows/columns output matrix. Optional. Default NULL.

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: pairwise distance matrix represents group membership. See details.

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: function creates binary triangular matrices representing categorical data pairwise distance matrix form. matrices represent group membership assigning 0 pairs observations belong category (individual, group, population) 1 belonging different categories. Binary pairwise matrices can useful evaluate association categorical continuous variable (represented pairwise distances) using Mantel test (Araya-Salas et al. 2019).

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0. Araya-Salas M, G Smith-vidaurre,  D Mennill, P González-Gómez, J Cahill & T Wright. 2019. Social group signatures hummingbird displays provide evidence co-occurrence vocal visual learning. Proceedings Royal Society B. 286: 20190666. Smouse PE, Long JC, Sokal RR. 1986 Multiple regression correlation extensions Mantel test matrix correspondence. Syst. Zool. 35, 627–632.

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Get binary triangular matrices — binary_triangular_matrix
code: { # create 3 groups each one with 2 observations groups <- paste0("G", rep(1:3, each = 2)) # create binary matrix binary_triangular_matrix(group = groups)  # create binary matrix using labels binary_triangular_matrix(group = groups, labels = paste(groups, 1:6, sep = "-")) }

what: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: distance_to_rectangular converts binary triangular matrices rectangular matrices using Multidimensional Scaling.

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
code: distance_to_rectangular(distance.matrix, labels = names(distance.matrix),  n.dimensions = 2, metric = TRUE, ...)

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: distance.matrix Distance matrix (.e. object class 'dist'). Can created using function dist converted using  .dist. labels Character vector factor containing labels used rows/columns output data frame. Default names(distance.matrix). Must length number observations 'distance.matrix'. n.dimensions Integer vector length 1 indicating number dimensions represent distances new space. Default 2. metric Logical argument control Metric (.k.. Classical, TRUE, default) Non-Metric MUltidimensional Scaling (FALSE) used project new n-dimension space. Non-Metric MDS conducted using function isoMDS Classical MDS uses function cmdscale. yes, silly wrapper 2 functions. ... Additional arguments passed isoMDS.

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: data frame new dimensions representing position observations new n-dimension space. metric = FALSE output data frame embedded list also includes stress value.

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: silly wrapper 2 multidimensional scaling functions (isoMDS cmdscale) simplifies calculation Multidimensional Scaling formatting output used functions package.

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Convert pairwise distance matrices to rectangular matrices — distance_to_rectangular
code: { data("example_space")  dist_example <- dist(example_space[example_space$ID %in% c("G1", "G2"),  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2")])  # convert into a 2-dimension space rect_example <- distance_to_rectangular(distance.matrix = dist_example, metric = TRUE)  head(rect_example)  # \donttest{ # convert into a 2-dimension space with non-metric MDS rect_example <- distance_to_rectangular(distance.matrix = dist_example,  metric = FALSE, maxit = 3)  # } }

title: Example bi-dimensional space data — example_space
text: example_space data frame 1550 observations simulated phenotypic bi-dimensional space including 5 groups.

title: Example bi-dimensional space data — example_space
code: data(example_space)

title: Example bi-dimensional space data — example_space
text: object class data.frame 1550 rows 4 columns.

title: Example bi-dimensional space data — example_space
text: Marcelo Araya Salas, PhenotypeSpace

title: Example bi-dimensional space data — example_space
code: { # load data data("example_space")  #plot space  xs <- tapply(example_space$Dimension_1, example_space$ID, mean) ys <- tapply(example_space$Dimension_2, example_space$ID, mean) plot(example_space[, c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2")],     col = example_space$color, pch = 20, cex = 1.8) text(xs, ys, labels = names(xs), cex = 2.5) }

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: plot_space plots bidimensional trait spaces

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
code: plot_space(X, dimensions, indices, basecex = 1, title = NULL,  colors = c("#3E4A89FF", "#35B779FF"), point.alpha = 0.7,  background.indices = NULL, pch = 1, labels = c("sub-space", "total space"),  legend.pos = "topright", density.alpha = 0.6)

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) total trait space. required extent plotting area represents overall trait space sub-space found. dimensions Character vector length 2 names columns containing dimensions phenotypic space. indices Numeric vector indices rows 'X' used sub-space plotting. basecex Numeric vector length 1 controlling relative size axis labels tick labels, legend title. Legend title multiply 1.5 (basecex * 1.5) increase size compare axis text. title Character vector length 1 used plot title. Default NULL. colors Character vector colors use density point plotting. 2 values must supplied 'background.indices' supplied. Default c("#3E4A89FF", "#35B779FF"). point.alpha Numeric vector length 1 >= 0 <= 1 alpha value color transparency. Default 0.7. 0 points plotted. background.indices Numeric vector indices rows 'X' used background traits space plotting. Points 'indices' plotted top points. pch Either integer specifying symbol single character used default plotting points. See points possible values interpretation. labels Character vector labels used legend. used legend.pos = NULL 'background.indices' supplied. Default c("sub-space", "total space"). legend.pos Controls position legend. Can take following values: "bottomright", "bottom", "bottomleft", "left", "topleft", "top", "topright" (default), "right" "center". NULL legend plotted. density.alpha Numeric vector length 1 >= 0 <= 1 alpha value color transparency used highest density regions. Lower density regions gradually increase transparency starting supplied value. Default 0.6. 0 densities plotted.

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: single panel plot active graphic device.

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: function plots sub-group data (.e. sub-space) within overall trait space. total trait space can also plotted background. default points kernel densities shown. Graphs returned active graphic device.

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Plot bidimensional trait spaces — plot_space
code: { data("example_space")  # no background plot_space(X = example_space, dimensions = c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),  indices = which(example_space$ID == "G2"))  # add background plot_space(X = example_space, dimensions = c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),  indices = which(example_space$ID == "G2"), background.indices = which(example_space$ID != "G2"))  # change legend labels plot_space(X = example_space, dimensions = c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),  indices = which(example_space$ID == "G2"), background.indices = which(example_space$ID != "G2"),  labels = c("G3", "trait space"))  # change legend position plot_space(X = example_space, dimensions = c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),  indices = which(example_space$ID == "G2"), background.indices = which(example_space$ID != "G2"),  labels = c("G3", "trait space"), legend.pos = "left")  # with title plot_space(X = example_space, dimensions = c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),  indices = which(example_space$ID == "G2"), background.indices = which(example_space$ID != "G2"),  labels = c("G3", "trait space"), legend.pos = "bottomleft", title = "G3") }

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: rarefact_space_similarity

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
code: rarefact_space_similarity(X, dimensions, group, n = NULL, replace = FALSE,  seed = NULL, parallel = 1, pb = TRUE, iterations = 30, ...)

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) categorical factor column group labels. dimensions Character vector names columns containing dimensions phenotypic space. group Character vector name column (character factor) containing group labels. n Integer vector length 1 indicating number samples use rarefaction (.e. many samples per group gather iteration). Default minimum sample size across groups. replace Logical argument control sampling done replacement. Default FALSE. seed Integer vector length 1 setting seed (see set.seed). used results different runs, makes replicable. parallel Integer vector length 1. Controls whether parallel computing applied. specifies number cores used. Default 1 (.e. parallel computing). pb Logical argument control progress bar shown. Default TRUE. iterations Integer vector length 1. Controls number times rarefaction routine iterated. Default 30. ... Additional arguments passed space_similarity customizing similarity measurements.

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: data frame containing mean, minimum, maximum standard deviation similarity metric across iterations pair groups. similarity metric symmetric (e.g. proportional area overlaps B necessarily area B overlaps , see space_similarity) separated columns supplied two comparisons.

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: function applies rarefaction sub-sampling procedure evaluating pairwise space similarity (internally using space_similarity). spread shape phenotypic space might change function number samples. Hence, ideally, spaces compared groups similar sample sizes. Rarefaction allows compare groups unbalanced sample sizes randomly re-sampling observations using number samples across groups iteratively.

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Calculates rarefacted space overlaps — rarefact_space_similarity
code: { # load data data("example_space")  # get proportion of space that overlaps (try with more iterations on your own data) prop_overlaps <- rarefact_space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "proportional.overlap",  iterations = 5)  # get minimum convex polygon overlap for each group (non-symmetric) mcp_overlaps <- rarefact_space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", iterations = 5)  # convert to non-symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(mcp_overlaps, symmetric = FALSE) }

code: { # load data data("example_space")  # get rarefied size difference using MCP (try with more iterations on your own data) mcp_size_diff <- rarefact_space_size_difference( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mcp",  iterations = 5)  # convert to non-symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(mcp_size_diff, symmetric = FALSE) }

what: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: rectangular_to_triangular converts rectangular pairwise matrices output many PhenotypeSpace functions triangular pairwise matrices.

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
code: rectangular_to_triangular(X, distance = TRUE, symmetric = TRUE)

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) categorical factor column group labels. observation (row) must contain pairwise value related labels 'groups' compared. first two columns must contain group labels appear rows (1 column) column names (2 column) output triangular matrix. third column (fourth column symmetric = FALSE) must numeric values included output triangular matrix. distance Logical argument control input data contains pairwise distances (dissimilarities) similarities. TRUE diagonal values filled 0, otherwise filled 1. Note diagonal values can set diag. symmetric Logical argument define values duplicated -diagonal triangles (symmetric triangular matrix, symmetric = TRUE, default) triangle filled values different columns (non-symmetric triangular matrix, symmetric = FALSE). latter upper triangle filled first column lower triangle second column. case, fourth column numeric values supplied.

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: pairwise triangular matrix.

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: function converts rectangular pairwise matrices output many PhenotypeSpace functions triangular pairwise matrices. takes data frame observation (row) contains pairwise value related labels 'groups' compared. first two columns must contain group labels appear rows (1 column) column names (2 column) output triangular matrix. third column (fourth column symmetric = FALSE) must numeric values included output triangular matrix.

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Convert rectangular pairwise matrices to triangular matrices — rectangular_to_triangular
code: { # load data data("example_space")  # get proportion of space that overlaps  prop_overlaps <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "proportional.overlap")  # get symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(prop_overlaps)  # get minimum convex polygon overlap for each group (non-symmetric) mcp_overlaps <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mcp.overlap")  # get a non-symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(mcp_overlaps, symmetric = FALSE) }

what: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: space_similarity estimate pairwise similarities phenotype spaces

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
code: space_similarity(X, dimensions, group, parallel = 1, type = "mcp.overlap",  pb = TRUE, outliers = 0.95, pairwise.scale = FALSE, distance.method = "Euclidean")

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) categorical factor column group labels. dimensions Character vector names columns containing dimensions phenotypic space. similarity metrics using overlap 2 dimensions required. Distance metrics can used number dimensions. group Character vector name column (character factor) containing group labels. parallel Integer vector length 1. Controls whether parallel computing applied. specifies number cores used. Default 1 (.e. parallel computing). type Character vector length 1. Controls type (di)similarity metric compare phenotypic sub-spaces two groups time. Seven metrics available quantify pairwise sub-space overlap ('similarity') pairwise distance sub-spaces ('dissimilarity'): density.overlap: proportion phenotypic sub-spaces area overlap, taking account irregular densities sub-spaces. Two groups share higher density areas similar similar sub-spaces share lower density areas. Two values supplied proportion space overlaps B necessarily proportion B overlaps . Similarity metric (higher values means similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 6 observations. mean.density.overlap: similar 'density.overlap' two values merged single pairwise mean overlap. Similarity metric (higher values means similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 6 observations. mcp.overlap: proportion phenotypic sub-spaces area overlap, areas calculated minimum convex polygon observations su-space. Two values supplied proportion space overlaps B necessarily proportion B overlaps . Similarity metric (higher values means similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 5 observations. mean.mcp.overlap: similar 'mcp.overlap' two values merged single pairwise mean overlap. Similarity metric (higher values means similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 5 observations. proportional.overlap: proportion joint area sub-spaces overlaps (overlapped area / total area groups). Sub-space areas calculated minimum convex polygon. Similarity metric (higher values means similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 5 observations. distance: mean euclidean pairwise distance observations compared sub-spaces. Dissimilarity metric (higher values means less similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 1 observation. centroid.distance: euclidean distance centroid compared sub-spaces. Dissimilarity metric (higher values means less similar). minimum sample size (per group) must 1 observation. pb Logical argument control progress bar shown. Default TRUE. outliers Numeric vector length 1. value 0 1 controlling proportion outlier observations excluded. Outliers determined farthest away sub-space centroid. pairwise.scale Logical argument control pairwise phenotypic spaces scaled (.e. z-transformed) prior similarity estimation. (TRUE) similarities decoupled size global phenotypic space. Useful compare similarities coming different phenotypic spaces. Default FALSE. available 'density.overlap' 'mean.density.overlap'. distance.method Character vector length 1 indicating method used measuring distances (hence applicable distances calculated). Default 'Euclidean'. distance similarity measures available dist can used (note apply continuous data). Check available metrics running summary(proxy::pr_DB). similarity measure used similarities converted distances.

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: data frame containing similarity metric pair groups. similarity metric symmetric (e.g. proportional area overlaps B necessarily area B overlaps , see space_similarity) separated columns supplied two comparisons.

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: function quantifies pairwise similarity phenotypic sub-spaces. Similarity evaluated overlap (similarity) distance (dissimilarity) group.

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Pairwise similarities of phenotype spaces — space_similarity
code: { # load data data("example_space")  # get proportion of space that overlaps  prop_overlaps <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "proportional.overlap")  #' # get symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(prop_overlaps)  # get minimum convex polygon overlap for each group (non-symmetric) mcp_overlaps <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mcp.overlap")  # convert to non-symmetric triangular matrix rectangular_to_triangular(mcp_overlaps, symmetric = FALSE)  # check available distance measures  summary(proxy::pr_DB)  # get eculidean distances (default) area_dist <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "distance", distance.method = "Euclidean")  # get Canberra distances  area_dist <- space_similarity( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "distance", distance.method = "Canberra") }

what: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
text: space_size

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
code: space_size(X, dimensions = NULL, group, parallel = 1, type = "mcp",  pb = TRUE, outliers = 0.95, ...)

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) categorical factor column group labels. dimensions Character vector names columns containing dimensions phenotypic space. group Character vector name column (character factor) containing group labels. parallel Integer vector length 1. Controls whether parallel computing applied. specifies number cores used. Default 1 (.e. parallel computing). type Character vector length 1. Controls type metric used quantifying space size. Three metrics available: mcp: minimum convex polygon area using function  mcp. minimum sample size (per group) must 2 observations. density: kernel density area using function kernelUD. minimum sample size (per group) must 6 observations. mst: minimum spanning tree using function spantree. minimum sample size (per group) must 5 observations. method expected robust influence outliers. pb Logical argument control progress bar shown. Default TRUE. outliers Numeric vector length 1. value 0 1 controlling proportion outlier observations excluded. Outliers determined farthest away sub-space centroid. ... Additional arguments passed kernelUD kernel density estimation ( type = 'density'.

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
text: data frame containing phenotypic space size group.

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Estimates the size of phenotypic spaces — space_size
code: { # load data data("example_space")  # plot data xs <- tapply(example_space$Dimension_1, example_space$ID, mean) ys <- tapply(example_space$Dimension_2, example_space$ID, mean) plot(example_space[, c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2")],  col = example_space$color, pch = 20, cex = 1.8) text(xs, ys, labels = names(xs), cex = 2.5)  # MCP spaces space_size( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mcp")  # MST  space_size(   X = example_space,   dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"),   group = "ID",   type = "mst") }

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
text: X Data frame containing columns dimensions phenotypic space (numeric) categorical factor column group labels. dimensions Character vector names columns containing dimensions phenotypic space. group Character vector name column (character factor) containing group labels. parallel Integer vector length 1. Controls whether parallel computing applied. specifies number cores used. Default 1 (.e. parallel computing). type Character vector length 1. Controls type metric used quantifying space size. Three metrics available: mcp: minimum convex polygon area using function  mcp. minimum sample size (per group) must 2 observations. density: kernel density area using function kernelUD. minimum sample size (per group) must 6 observations. mst: minimum spanning tree using function spantree. minimum sample size (per group) must 5 observations. method expected robust influence outliers. pb Logical argument control progress bar shown. Default TRUE. outliers Numeric vector length 1. value 0 1 controlling proportion outlier observations excluded. Outliers determined farthest away sub-space centroid. ... Additional arguments passed space_size customizing space size calculation.

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
text: data frame containing space size difference pair groups.

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
text: function estimates pairwise size difference phenotypic space simple subtraction sizes two spaces. can seen additional metric similarity complementing found space_similarity.

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
text: Araya-Salas, M, & K. Odom. 2022, PhenotypeSpace: R package quantify compare phenotypic trait spaces R package version 0.1.0.

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
text: Marcelo Araya-Salas marcelo.araya@ucr.ac.cr)

title: Estimates pairwise size differences of phenotypic spaces — space_size_difference
code: { # load data data("example_space")  # MCP size (try with more iterations on your own data) mcp_size <- space_size_difference( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mcp")  # MST size mcp_size <- space_size_difference( X = example_space, dimensions =  c("Dimension_1", "Dimension_2"), group = "ID", type = "mst") }
